statement.paragraphs: $gcd(a, b)$ of $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}$ is the largest positive integer $d$ which divides both $a$ and $b$ (Notation: $d | a$ and $d | b$).

newcol.paragraphs: If $a \neq 0$, then $gcd(a, 0) = \abs{a}$. $gcd(0, 0)$ is undefined.

slide.section_title: Further Results in Elementary Number Theory

newcol.paragraphs: If $b = aq + r$ $(a, b, q, r \in \mathbb{Z})$, then $gcd(b, a) = gcd (a, r)$.

If $d | a$ and $d | b$, then $d | r = b - aq$. Conversely, if $d | a$ and $d | r$, then $d|a$ and $d|b = qa+r$. So, the set of common divisors of $a, b$ is the same as the set of the common divisors of $a, r$. If two finite sets of integers are the same, then their largest elements are clearly the same. In other words: \[ gcd(b, a) = gcd(a, r). \]

statement.title: Bézout's Lemma
Bézout's Lemma
statement.paragraphs: Let $a, b$ be nonzero integers. There exist $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $gcd(a, b) = ax + by$.

newcol.paragraphs: Recall the notation used in
. We saw that if $r_n = 0$, then $gcd(a, b) = r_{n - 1}$.
We may prove Bézout's Lemma via mathematical induction as follows:

collapse.paragraphs: First, for integers $0 \leq l < \min(n - 1, 2)$, show that there exist $x_l, y_l \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $r_l = a x_l + b y_l$. This is the base step of the induction proof.
We now carry out the inductive step. Suppose $n - 1 \geq 2$. For any integer $2 \leq k \leq n - 1$, suppose $r_l = a x_l + b y_l$ for some $x_l, y_l \in \mathbb{Z}$, for all $0\leq l < k$.
Show that: \[r_k = \underbrace{b_k}_{a_{k - 1} = r_{k - 2}} - q_{k} \underbrace{a_{k}}_{r_{k - 1}}\] also has the form $r_k = a x_k + b y_k$ for some $x_k, y_k \in \mathbb{Z}$.
The desired identity $gcd(a, b) = r_{n - 1} = ax_{n - 1} + by_{n - 1}$ then follows by mathemtical induction.

newcol.paragraphs: Consider the set: \[S = \{n \in \mathbb{Z}_{> 0} | n = ax + by \text{ for some } x, y \in \mathbb{Z}\}.\] Show that the the minimum element $d \in S$ is the greatest common divisor of $a$ and $b$.
Find $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that: \[gcd(285, 255) = 285 x + 255 y.\]
For any nonzero $a, b$ in the group $G = (\mathbb{Z}, +)$, we have: \[ \langle a, b \rangle = \langle gcd(a, b) \rangle. \]

newcol.paragraphs: Two integers $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}$ are relatively prime if and only if there exist $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $ax + by = 1$.
If $a, b$ are relatively prime, then by definition $gcd(a, b) = 1$. So, by

there exist $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that: \[ax + by = gcd(a, b) = 1.\] Conversely, suppose $ax + by = 1$ for some $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}$. Then, any common divisor of $a$ and $b$ must also be a divisor of $1$. Since $1$ is only divisible by $\pm 1$, we conclude that $gcd(a, b) = 1$.

newcol.paragraphs: Let $a, b$ be integers. If $p$ is prime and $p | ab$, then $p$ divides at least one of $a$ and $b$.

Suppose $p$ does not divide $b$ (Notation: $p\nmid b$), then $gcd(p, b) = 1$, which implies that $1 = px + by$ for some $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}$. Since $p | apx$ and $p | aby$, we have $p | a = a\underbrace{(px + by)}_{= 1}$.

statement.paragraphs: If $a, b$ are relatively prime and $a | bc$, then $a | c$.

newcol.paragraphs: If $a, b$ are relatively prime and: \[ a | c, \quad b | c, \] then: \[ ab | c. \]
By assumption, there are $s, t \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that: \[ c = as = bt. \]

collapse.paragraphs: So, $a | as = bt$, which by
implies that $a | t$, since $gcd(a, b) = 1$.
Hence, $t = au$ for some $u \in \mathbb{Z}$, and we have $c = bt = ab u$. It follows that $ab | c$.

statement.title: The Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic
The Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic
statement.paragraphs: Let $a$ be a positive integer $\geq 2$. Then,

col_li.paragraphs: The integer $a$ is either a prime or a product of primes.
The integer $a$ may be written uniquely as \[ a = p_1^{n_1}p_2^{n_2}\cdots p_l^{n_l}, \] where $p_1, p_2, \cdots, p_l$ are distinct prime numbers, and $n_1, n_2, \ldots, n_l \in \mathbb{N}$.

newcol.paragraphs: We prove Part 1 of the theorem by contradiction.

collapse.paragraphs: Suppose there exist positive integers $\geq 2$ which are neither primes nor products of primes.
Let $m$ be the smallest such integer. Since $m$ is not prime, there are positive integers $a, b \neq 1$ such that $m = ab$.
In particular, $a, b < m$. So, $a$ and $b$ must be either primes or products of primes, which implies that $m$ is itself a product of primes, a contradiction.
We now prove Part 2 (
) of the theorem by induction.
The base step corresponds to the case $l = 1$.
Suppose: \[ a = p_1^{n_1} = q_1^{m_1}q_2^{m_2}\cdots q_k^{m_k}, \] where $p_1$ is prime, and the $q_i$'s are distinct primes, and $n_1, m_i \in \mathbb{N}$.
Then, $p_1$ divides the right-hand side, so by Euclid's Lemma $p_1$ divides one of the $q_i$'s.
Since the $q_i$'s are prime, we may assume (reindexing if necessary) that $p_1 = q_1$.
Suppose $k > 1$. If $n_1 > m_1$, then $p_1^{n_1 - m_1} = q_2^{m_2}\cdots q_k^{m_k}$, which implies that $p_1 = q_1$ is one of $q_2,\ldots, q_k$, a contradiction, since the $q_i$'s are distinct.
If $n_1 \leq m_1$, then $1 = p_1^{m_1 - n_1}q_2^{m_2}\cdots q_k^{m_k}$, which is impossible. We conclude that $k = 1$, and $p_1 = q_1$, $n_1 = m_1$.

Now we establish the inductive step: Suppose unique factorization is true for all positive integers $a'$ which may be written as $a' = p_1^{n_1}p_2^{n_2}\cdots p_{l'}^{n_{l'}}$, for any $l' < l$. We want to show that it is also true for any integer $a$ which may be written as $a = p_1^{n_1}p_2^{n_2}\cdots p_{l}^{n_{l}}$.

In other words, suppose \[ a = p_1^{n_1}p_2^{n_2}\cdots p_{l}^{n_{l}} = q_1^{m_1}\cdots q_k^{m_k}, \] where $p_i, q_i$ are prime and $n_i, m_i \in \mathbb{N}$. We want to show that $k = l$, and $p_i = q_i$, $n_i = m_i$, for $i = 1, 2, \ldots, l$.
If $k < l$, then by the inductive hypothesis applied to $l' = k < l$, we have $k = l$, a contradiction. So, we may assume that $k \geq l$.
By Euclid's Lemma, $p_l$ divides, and hence must be equal to, one of the $q_i$'s.

Reindexing if necessary, we may assume that $p_l = q_k$. Cancelling $p_l$ and $q_{k}$ from both sides of the equation, it is also clear that $n_l = m_{k}$. Hence, we have: \[ p_1^{n_1}p_2^{n_2}\cdots p_{l-1}^{n_{l-1}} = q_1^{m_1}\cdots q_{k-1}^{m_{k -1}}. \] Since $l - 1 < l$, we may now apply the inductive hypothesis to the integer which is equal to the left-hand side of the above equation, and conclude that $l - 1 = k -1$, $p_i = q_i$, $n_i = m_i$, for $1\leq i \leq l - 1$.
Since we already know that $p_l^{n_l}$ matches $q_{k}^{m_{k}}$, we have $l = k$, and $p_i = q_i$, $n_i = m_i$, for $1 \leq i \leq l$. This establishes the inductive step, and completes the proof.

statement.paragraphs: Let $m$ be a positive integer, then $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}$ are said to be:

newcol.paragraphs: The congruence relation $\equiv$ is an
. In other words, it is:

li.paragraphs: $a \equiv b \mod m$ implies that $b \equiv a \mod m$;
$a \equiv b \mod m$, $b \equiv c \mod m$, imply that $a \equiv c \mod m$.

newcol.paragraphs: Since $m | 0 = (a - a)$, we have $a\equiv a \mod m$.
If $a \equiv b \mod m$, then by definition $m$ divides $a - b$. But if $m$ divides $a - b$, it must also divide $-(a - b) = b - a$, which implies that $b \equiv a \mod m$.
If $m | (a - b)$ and $m | (b - c)$, then $m | ((a - b) + (b - c)) = (a - c)$, which implies that $a \equiv c \mod m$.
$a \equiv 0 \mod m$ if and only if $m | a$.

li.paragraphs: If $a = qm + r$, then $a \equiv r \mod m$.
If $0 \leq r < r' < m$, then $r \not\equiv r' \mod m$.

newcol.paragraphs: Given integer $m \geq 2$, every $a \in \mathbb{Z}$ is congruent modulo $m$ to exactly one of $\{0, 1, 2, \ldots, m - 1\}$.
By Part 1 of the claim, $a$ is congruent mod $m$ to the remainder $r$ of the division of $a$ by $m$.

collapse.paragraphs: By definition, the remainder $r$ lies in $\{0, 1, 2, \ldots, m - 1\}$. If $a \equiv r' \mod m$, for some $r' \in \{0, 1, 2, \ldots, m - 1\}$, then by transitivity, we have $r' \equiv r \mod m$.
By Part 2 of the claim, we have $r = r'$.

statement.paragraphs: Congruence is compatible with addition and multiplication in the following sense:

newcol.paragraphs: If $a \equiv a' \mod m$, and $b \equiv b' \mod m$, then $a + b \equiv a'+ b'\mod m$.
If $a \equiv a' \mod m$ and $b \equiv b' \mod m$, then $ab \equiv a'b' \mod m$.
If $m | (a - a')$ and $m | (b - b')$, then: \[ m | (a - a') + (b - b') = (a + b) - (a' + b'). \] So, $a + b \equiv a' + b' \mod m$.
If $m | (a - a')$ and $m | (b - b')$, then: \[ m | (a - a')b + a'(b - b') = (ab - a'b'). \] So, $ab \equiv a'b' \mod m$.
By
, any $a \in \mathbb{Z}$ is congruent modulo $8$ to exactly one element in $\{0, 1, 2, \ldots, 7\}$. So, by
, $a^2$ is congruent modulo 8 to one of: \[ \{0^2, 1^2, 2^2, 3^2, 4^2, 5^2, 6^2, 7^2\} = \{0, 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, 36, 49\}. \] The numbers above a congruent modulo 8 to 0, 1, or 4. The claim follows.

statement.paragraphs: If $a$ and $m$ are relatively prime, then there exists $x \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $ax \equiv 1 \mod m$.

newcol.paragraphs: Since $a$ and $m$ are relatively prime, by
there exist $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that: \[ ax + my = 1. \]

collapse.paragraphs: This implies that $m$ divides $my = 1 - ax$. So, by definition, we have $ax \equiv 1 \mod m$.

statement.title: Chinese Remainder Theorem
Chinese Remainder Theorem

newcol.paragraphs: In other words, the system of two congruence relations is equivalent to a single congruence relation: \[ x \equiv r \mod m_1 m_2 \] for some $r \in \mathbb{Z}$.

collapse.paragraphs: Applying this process repeatedly, a system of congruence relations of the form: \begin{align*} x &\equiv& r_1 &\mod m_1 \\ x &\equiv& r_2 &\mod m_2 \\ & & \vdots &\\ x &\equiv& r_l &\mod m_l \end{align*} where the $m_i$'s are pairwise coprime, is equivalent to a single relation of the form: \[ x \equiv r \mod m_1m_2\cdots m_l \] for some $r \in \mathbb{Z}$.

newcol.paragraphs: Since $m_1$ and $m_2$ are relatively prime, by
there exists $n \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $m_1n \equiv 1 \mod m_2$. Let $x = m_1n(r_2 - r_1) + r_1$.

collapse.paragraphs: Since: \[ m_1 n (r_2 - r_1) \equiv 0 \mod m_1, \] we have: \[ x \equiv r_1 \mod m_1. \]

Moreover, since $m_1n \equiv 1 \mod m_2$, we have: \[ x = m_1n(r_2 - r_1) + r_1 \equiv r_2 - r_1 + r_1 \equiv r_2 \mod m_2. \] This shows that the system of congruence relations has at least one solution.
If $x'$ is another solution to the system, then:
So, $m_1 | (x - x')$ and $m_2 | (x - x')$. Since, $m_1, m_2$ are relatively prime, by a previous result we conclude that $m_1m_2 | (x - x')$. In other words, $x \equiv x' \mod m_1m_2$.
Conversely, for any integer $k$, it is clear $x' = x + m_1m_2k$ is also a solution provided that $x$ is a solution.
Hence, the solution set to the system of congruence relations may be described by: \[ x \equiv x_0 \mod m_1m_2, \] where $x_0$ is any particular solution to the system.

slide.paragraphs: The proof of the Chinese Remainder Theorem as written above is complete. However, it is worthwhile to explain how we come up with the solution $x = m_1n(r_2 - r_1) + r_1$ in the first place.

newcol.paragraphs: Heuristically, the solution may be arrived at as follows: For any $q \in \mathbb{Z}$, $x = m_1 q + r_1$ is a solution to the first congruence relation. We want to find $q$ such that $m_1 q + r_1$ is also a solution to the second congruence relation, that is: \[ m_1 q + r_1 \equiv r_2 \mod m_2 \]

collapse.paragraphs: or, equivalently, \[ m_1 q \equiv r_2 - r_1 \mod m_2. \tag{$\ast$} \]
Noting that there exists an $n \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $m_1 n \equiv 1 \mod m_2$, the congruence relation $(\ast)$ is equivalent to: \[ q \equiv n(r_2 - r_1) \mod m_2. \]

Hence, $x = m_1 q + r_1$ is a solution to the system of congruence relations if and only if $q$ is of the form $m_2l + n(r_2 - r_1)$, where $l \in \mathbb{Z}$. In particular, $l = 0$ gives $q = n(r_2 - r_1)$. Hence, $x = m_1n(r_2 - r_1) + r_1$ is a solution.

newcol.paragraphs: The relation \eqref{eq:crteg1} holds if and only if: \[ x = 34s + 3 \] for some $s \in \mathbb{Z}$.

collapse.paragraphs: Since $gcd(34, 27) = 1$, by

there exists $a \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $a\cdot 34 \equiv 1 \mod 27$. To find $a$, we perform the Euclidean Algorithm on $34$ and $27$: \[ \begin{split} 34 &= 27 \cdot 1 + 7\\ 27 &= 7 \cdot 3 + 6\\ 7 &= 6 \cdot 1 + 1\\ 6 &= 1\cdot 6 + 0 \end{split} \]
Working backwards from the last equation, we see that: \[ 1 = 34(4) + 27(-5) \] Hence: \[ 27 | (1 - 34\cdot 4 ) \] That is, $34 \cdot 4 \equiv 1 \mod 27$. So, we may take $a = 4$.

Multiplying both sides of \eqref{eq:crteg3} by $a = 4$, we see that \eqref{eq:crteg3} holds if and only if: \[ s \equiv -16 \mod 27, \] which is equivalent to: \[ s \equiv 11 \mod 27. \] Since the relation above holds if and only if $s = 27t + 11$ for some $t \in \mathbb{Z}$, we conclude that $x \in \mathbb{Z}$ is a solution to our system of congruence relations if and only if: \[ x = 34s + 3 = 34(27t + 11) + 3 = (34)(27)t + 377 \] for some $t \in \mathbb{Z}$. More concisely, the solution set to the system of congruence relations is represented by the single relation: \[ x \equiv 377 \mod 34\cdot 27 \]
